data.text: How Do You Deal with the Heat on Bike Tours?

Dealing with the heat: what are your methods to ride 100+ km days in the heat 35C+? Currently 30-35C here in Wyoming and I wet my sun sleeves and buff, drinking water. Still got a headache, so maybe should drink more water and rest. Anything else that you do to manage the heat? Thanks!

When it gets too hot is best to go take a nap somewhere and go on later until sunset or even into the night, also try to choose roads with shade (next to a mountain range, forest, avoid wide big roads as the often have no shade

data.text: I met a bike traveler in France who shared with me his method for cycle touring in the heat of summer. He would get up early and ride as far as he could. Then when it got too hot to ride, he would find a shady place to rest for a few hours. Being France, there were lots of shady places. When the late afternoon began to cool the temps, he got back on the bike and cycled until it got close to dark and he had to find a camping spot. This man was much younger than me and I am sure a much stronger rider, but he was also carrying much more gear.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: Take lots of breaks in the shade, even if the only shade you can find is behind a telephone pole, street sign, etc. Every little bit helps. One of my favorite tricks: Take a cotton bandana (square) and put some crushed ice in the middle. Fold it into a triangle, then roll it up from the long edge. Tie this around your neck, trying to keep the ice on the large blood vessels in your neck. This will help keep your head a bit cooler. As the ice melts the cool water will run down your neck & chest, providing a bit more cooling.

data.text: Ice water (lot of ice) in a camelback in my backpack helps keep my core cool a long time riding in the Texas heat with temps over 100*F. I am pretty adapted to the heat but always ice water on my back, frogg toggs brand cooling towels for my neck, taking breaks to re-wet my towel and wipe down, vented helmet for sure and i‚Äôll pour water in my helmet if i‚Äôm really feeling the heat to help cool my head. I only drink to thirst, never gorge bcuz it just flushes out more electrolytes. I also take a himalayan salt shot every 2 hours. (Salt shot = 1/4 tsp crushed himalayan salt with a shot of water.) I also love drinking pickle juice and always pack it to go. Can freeze it in pouches and carry with and drink as it melts. I never eat during rides, i have the best performance and endurance in a fasted state. Plus digesting food diverts energy into the digestion process and u need all the energy u can get imo.
data.author: Laura Michelle

data.text: For me, water and electrolytes.... I did a short 5-day tour with 100km days, and i was using close to 1L of water per hour. Small amount of that i was pouring on my head and helmet :) and in every 3rd liter i dropped electrolyte soluble tabs. Plus, i was eating regular cheese and salami sandwiches, so you have carbs from bread and protein and fat from cheese and meat. I figured out i can't tour only on carbs.

data.text: Cool your core and your brain box! They make vests that you soak in water then wear. Cools your core. They make a neck scarf that swells with water when you soak it and you wear around you neck. Cools the blood going to your brain. Cools the brain box. Use powdered or tablet electrolytes. Drink before, during, and after your ride. Drink until your full then drink more. Drink even when you're not thirsty. Thirsty means you're behind the hydration curve and headed for trouble, leg and abdominal cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. The last 2 can kill.
